displayed_text: Patient: Anyway… Doctor: You’re gonna need that. When is the neurosurgeon appointment? Patient: Next week. Doctor: Okay. Alright because I think we are going to have to hold off a lot of decisions then for their input. Patient: If there’s a decision to be made I mean… Doctor: About your treatment, yeah. If it’s surveillance it’s easy because we’re sort of… Patient: Oh yeah. That’s the best case scenario. Doctor: …then the cancer is giving us a break and you can deal with your… Patient: Right other stuff. Doctor: …neck issue and spine and penis issue too. Laughs]] Family Member: Yeah. Doctor: Now that we’re on tape let’s document this. It’s real. You have to face it.

Patient: I wasn’t on a ladder. Doctor: Uh huh. And I think you know; I mean your body will tell you. If he really poops out, no matter what he really wants to do, it’s not gonna happen. But I think you got to get off the Xtandi, which will help you with your energy. I’ll start the process for the Xofigo, and I’m gonna give you the side-effects sheet to start when Dr. ____ reviews the whole thing with you. Family Member: How long will this take? Doctor: It’s once a month. Oh you mean the – oh it’s like a few weeks. Family Member: So. Doctor: Yeah, the Xofigo. Family Member: Xofigo. Doctor: Yeah. Family Member: Do you think he’s qualified to go away on a vacation for a couple of weeks? Doctor: Uh hum, yeah – when are you going? Healthcare Professional: When are you going on vacation? Doctor: Yeah, I get to go.

Family Member: Prostate. Patient: For prostate. (Chuckles) Doctor: So in the end you’re taking the blood pressure medicine and the Vitamin D. Patient: Correct. Doctor: That’s it. Patient: That’s it. Doctor: No other medicines for pain, anything else for the allergies – Patient: No. Doctor: Or vitamins? Patient: No. Doctor: Okay. And when you were in the hospital, did they put any tubes or anything in, anything of that you still have. Patient: Yes, they put catheter in and uh they gave me I.V. at the beginning and made sure the catheter was out.

Patient: The ARV seven has to stay positive and, uh, (stuff) Doctor: Right. Next time you come in, we’re gonna be in a new building. Patient: Oh boy! Doctor: Across the street. Family Member: Are you sort of surprised he’s not in pain? Doctor: No. Family Member: Okay. Doctor: Uh, the – we always ask about pain, you know. Family Member: Yeah. Doctor: So, because pain does mean -- pain means we gotta do something now. Family Member: I get it. Doctor: Most people don’t have pain. Family Member: Okay.

Patient: So when I do get, when do I get my tickets? Doctor: Well, once, first, you have to sign the consent and do all the screening. Then we can register you and start booking the, the tickets, and whatnot. Patient: Here’s the papers I sign? Doctor: This is not the paper. Doctor: We have to bring you- Family Member: He didn’t care. Doctor: Multiple. Healthcare Professional: Excuse me. He did have labs done. Doctor: Yeah. He told me that. So the PSA is what? Healthcare Professional: Sixty. Doctor: Sixty? So here it’s sixty point four. (Sound Door closes) Patient: No. I want it. I want to get it over with.

Patient: Um hmm. Doctor: …it continues to rise. Patient: Um hmm. Doctor: And in those patients we may offer radiation therapy, radiation therapy with hormonal therapy. Patient: Um hmm. Doctor: But we’ll wait and see what happens in your case. Patient: I’ve been praying that… Doctor: We removed it and the fact that we removed it may minimize the reoccurrence. Patient: Um hmm. Doctor: So we’ll see. Patient: Um hmm. Well that’s why I want to go that route you know. Doctor: Yeah and you did the right thing.

Patient: Okay. Doctor: So alright well let’s, let’s continue with the same course. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: And see what happens, alright? Patient: Um hum. I’ve been working and so, so you know, I’ve been keeping busy without that. Doctor: Okay. Okay. Alright. Very good. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: And, uh, any other medical problems? Heart or lungs or anything like that? Patient: No. The only problem I have is with my knee. I had, uh, uh, a cyst. Doctor: Um hum. Patient: Erupt in my knee. Doctor: I see it.

Patient: You gonna put me to sleep or what? Doctor: Oh, yeah. Yeah. You’ll be fine. Patient: Oh, man! No!!! Doc! C’mon! Doctor: You’ll be fine! Family Member: Seriously? Patient: How you goin’, do whatcha, you goin’ up my ass? What are you doin’? Doctor: No!!!! What is your fixation about the lower body parts? (Laughs) Patient: Well then – when you go -- how you gonna get to – how you gonna do the biopsy? You gonna cut me open? Doctor: No! You lay down on the CAT scan. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: They numb up an area right around here or here – Patient: Right.

Family Member: everyone gets chemo. Which is great for me, you’re like wow, I guess it’s great for you but you know we all have mixed feelings a little bit. I get that. Patient: Right. Doctor: The second study is chemotherapy plus an immunotherapy versus chemotherapy. So, docetaxel plus immunotherapy versus docetaxel. So, you know, either one of those is doable. Again, if you had stuff outside of bone that’s probably what we should do. Hi, oh, for the opioids, Okay, for your pain, yeah. So, then the other part is what if you’re just bone. So, let’s say we do this and you’re just in your bones, no lymph nodes, liver, nothing, it’s clean then I think we should consider radium or Xofigo. Family Member: Together with the docetaxel? Doctor: No, just radium. So, there it’s um to combine with anything else is not standard of care and we don’t have our trial up yet with radium plus something. But, at this moment standard of care is just monthly radium for six months and that improves your survival span. So does chemotherapy but radium you can only give if it’s just in bone. So, if you have it like in the liver or whatever kind of like when we first started Patient: Um hum. Doctor: it was like oh, no you kind of had these bits and pieces, Patient: Right. Doctor: one, your insurance won’t approve it and number two it’s the wrong treatment. Patient: Okay. Doctor: But, if that’s sort of gone and nowhere to be found on this CAT scan then I think radium is it. Now, radium does two things. One is that it helps you live longer but also helps with pain so those people who are, you know, whether you’re taking a Tylenol over-the-counter or you’re taking actual narcotics that should improve. Patient: Okay.

Patient: Good. Doctor: - but because they’re filming – Patient: Now. Doctor: - uh they wanted to see me with you – Patient: Yeah. Family Member: Yeah (Chuckles) Doctor: So he’s still very much a part of the team. Patient: Good. Family Member: We like him very much. (Chuckles) Doctor: Okay, anything else? Patient: That’s it. Family Member: That’s it. Doctor: Let me see what we have in here in terms of just follow-up. So he’s already set up for his shot.

Patient: All right, right. Doctor: We have a creatinine from when you did a quick you know CAT scan. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: But we’ll need; I’m sure we’ll need the full megillah. Patient: So what I need to just walk down there? Doctor: We may end up drawing it here. OH, OH, somebody’s eavesdropping. Come on in now. Healthcare Professional 1: Hi there. Hi, Mr. L___. Good to see you. How are you doing? Patient: Great, how are you? Doctor: Ah, I said, “You might need some blood work today.” Oh okay, that’s my ticket out; good-bye.

Patient: Right. Right. Doctor: Uh we often see after folks have been on what is also known as Zytiga- Patient: I was on it. Doctor: Yeah. We get, we get sort of resistance that carries through there. Patient: Ohh. Doctor: So that means uh we need to take you off. I mean the testosterone part of this, the input of the study was PSA going down. So you already, you have gone up a little. So you already hit that. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Previously, we’ve been letting people stay on the testosterone. They feel good plus their scans don’t look any worse. I think given that your PSA went up, you’re feeling good, and the scans are a little worse, maybe you should come off it. Patient: Okay. Doctor: And think about what’s next. Patient: Yeah. What is next? Doctor: Yeah. That’s the hard part of the day. Uh well I guess the first question is you sort of came here specifically for this. Are you going to, do you want to stay here for the next or is the next, do you want to go somewhere, to shop around?

Patient: Well, last time I got the bone scan in D___. Doctor: I know. Yes. Yes. Patient: B___ C___. Doctor: Yeah. Whatever. So in between, I may, I may just give you a script to hold on for a PSA. Okay? Patient: Yes. Yes. Doctor: Like six weeks or so. If the PSA creeps up a little bit, I may want that in-between lab work. Okay? But, otherwise, I, if everything looks good, and- Patient: Very good. Okay. Sounds good. Doctor: Okay? Family Member: So what would the, uh, CAT scan show today? Just soft tissue? Patient: She doesn’t know yet. Family Member: maybe it’ll show Doctor: Well, I think maybe his disease was mainly in the lymph nodes. So that is what we will be following and the spine is visible on the CAT scan, too. Family Member: Okay.

Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.

About how long has it been since you las.Within the past year (anytime less than: About how long has it been since you last saw a doctor or other health professional about your health?:::Within the past year (anytime less than 12 months ago)

During the past 12 months, not counting.2 times: During the past 12 months, not counting times you went to an emergency room, how many times did you go to a doctor, nurse, or other health professional to get care for yourself?:::2 times

Sometimes doctors care more about what i.disagree: Sometimes doctors care more about what is convenient for them than about their patients' medical needs.:::disagree

Doctors are extremely thorough and caref.neutral: Doctors are extremely thorough and careful.:::neutral

You completely trust doctors' decisions.neutral: You completely trust doctors' decisions about which medical treatments are best.:::neutral

A doctor would never mislead you about a.agree: A doctor would never mislead you about anything.:::agree

All in all, you trust doctors completely.neutral: All in all, you trust doctors completely.:::neutral

People of my ethnic group receive the sa.agree: People of my ethnic group receive the same medical care from doctors and healthcare workers as people from other groups:::agree

People of my ethnic group are treated th.agree: People of my ethnic group are treated the same as people of other groups by doctors and healthcare workers:::agree

Doctors have the best interests of peopl.agree: Doctors have the best interests of people of my ethnic group in mind:::agree

Which of the following best describe you.Employed: Which of the following best describe your current occupational status? Mark all that apply.:::Employed

What is the highest grade or level of s.College graduate: What is the highest grade or level of schooling you completed?:::College graduate

Are you of Hispanic or Latino origin or.Yes, Hispanic or Latino: Are you of Hispanic or Latino origin or descent?:::Yes, Hispanic or Latino

What race or races do you consider yours.Some other race: What race or races do you consider yourself to be?:::Some other race

displayed_text: Family Member: And we … Doctor: And until last time your PSA was coming down. Today’s I don’t know Family Member: Okay. Doctor: if it’s back yet. But everything else, the hemoglobin got slightly better. Family Member: Okay. Doctor: It went from ten point five to eleven point three. All of that, everything is improving in the right direction. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Okay. The CAT scan also looks good. Okay. Family Member: Okay. That’s good. That’s pleasing isn’t it J___. Doctor: Yeah. Patient: Yeah. Family Member: We’re frustrated. Doctor: But he’s doing okay?

Family Member: Right. Patient: Right, right, yeah. Doctor: So, so I just want to take a moment and pause and say we’ve got a serious problem here but it’s not a death sentence a year from now or two years from now. Patient: Right, right, right. Family Member: Uh hum. Doctor: Perspective. Patient: Yeah, yeah, yeah. Doctor: That’s one perspective, okay? Patient: Sure. Doctor: So the other thing, so we’ve got this fifty/fifty with the hormones and radiation. The question is what else can we do. Patient: Uh hum. Doctor: So what else we can do is we can hit what’s remaining as far as the cancer really hard right now and when I say really hard what we’re talking about is some chemotherapy, um which we give you through the vein every three weeks and we give you four doses of it. It’s a medicine called Taxotere. And we add in um uh, if we can get insurance to pay for it, but generally we can; we add in a super-hormone medicine called ah Zytiga or Addaram. It’s a pill you take ah every day. It’s four pills every day.
